awd_titl_txt: Continued Operation of the OSU/CEOAS Marine and Geology Repository
awd_abstract_narration:
The College of Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences at Oregon State University maintains the OSU/CEOAS Marine and Geology Repository (OSU-MGR) as an NSF-sponsored community facility. The mission is to archive and distribute geological samples, predominantly sediment cores, rocks, nodules and sediment trap samples, for scientific research and education. The repository was established in 1971 and since that time OSU-MGR has grown to curate four primary collections. (1) NSF’s Marine Geology Collection: Consisting of 15,196 m of marine sediments from 6,603 cores, 14,674 rock samples from 529 dredges, 568 rock samples from 61 dives (Alvin, ROV), 528 deep-sea manganese nodules, and 1,644 sediment trap samples. (2) NSF’s Antarctic core collection: Consisting of 16,187 m of marine sediments from 7,352 cores and 7,993 m of drill core from 92 sites, including ANDRILL, CRP, CIROS, DVDP and others. (3) NOAA R/V Okeanos Explorer Dive Collection: Consisting of 365 rocks from 187 dives. And (4) various other core and rock collections, including 567 m of Pacific NW lake sediments and 8,061 m of terrestrial drill core from across Oregon. For almost 50 years these materials have been archived and described with continuous NSF funding, with more than 186,000 samples distributed over the past 29 years to scientists, educators, and museums throughout the United States and around the world. With more than 27,000 samples taken over the last grant period, the demand for repository samples remains high, and is a predictable component of today’s scientific need.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Oregon State University Marine and Geology Repository (OSU-MGR) within the College of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences (CEOAS) has been continuously supported by NSF-OCE and OSU since 1972 as a community facility with a mission to facilitate research, education and the advancement of scientific knowledge through access and use of our diverse collection of rock, lake and marine sediment samples. Over the more than 50-year history of the OSU-MGR we have done this by archiving samples using best practices (for soft sediment this means continuous refrigeration) and to distribute samples and data upon request for scientific research and education. As in the past, NSF remains our primary source (>90%) of operating funds, and every two to five years we make a request for continued support to operate this national repository. OSU continues to provide support for renovations, facilities and instrument maintenance, utilities (including electricity for refrigerated/frozen storage and fuel for backup generators) and PI salaries. Our focus continues to be state-of-the-art curation services, while developing a modern digital online presence with the goal of increasing the value, searchability and discoverability of the entire collection. Data obtained and distributed on the collection itself along with outreach and education have been growing components of our mission.   

At the start of this grant cycle our holding included four primary collections. (1) NSF?s Marine Geology Collection: Consisting of 15,196 m of marine sediments from 6,603 cores, 14,674 rock samples from 529 dredges, 568 rock samples from 61 dives (Alvin, ROV), 528 deep-sea manganese nodules, and 1,644 sediment trap samples. (2) NSF?s Antarctic core collection: Consisting of 16,187 m of marine sediments from 7,352 cores and 7,993 m of drill core from 92 sites, including ANDRILL, CRP, CIROS, DVDP and other drill cores. (3) NOAA R/V Okeanos Explorer Dive Collection: Consisting of 365 rocks from 187 dives. (4) various other core and rock collections, including 567 m of Pacific Northwest Lake sediments and 8,061 m of terrestrial drill core from across Oregon.

The collection grew, with the addition of two significant legacy collections. 278 cores totaling 583 m from the Byrd Polar and Climate Research Center at Ohio State University and more than 1000 rocks from a variety of locations within the Pacific Ocean from the University of Hawaii, Manoa a dredge rock collection. Samples from 10 recent marine coring cruises arrived at the MGR with 116 cores totaling 245 m, one NSF dredge cruise (48 dredges), and 6 NOAA ROV dive cruises. Five different terrestrial coring operations brough in another 30 cores. After moratorium, all materials will be made available for sampling and advertised on our website.

Over the past two years we distributed 5108 samples to 24 US (non-OSU) researchers from 20 institutions, 2073 samples to 7 international Researchers, 2970 samples to 13 OSU Researchers.

We facilitate nondestructive data acquisition on samples within our collection for 17 researchers from 14 institutions for MGG part of the collection using our Track Lab within the OSU-MGR and taking samples to the Computed Tomographic (CT) scanner at the OSU College of Veterinary Medicine. Additionally, undergraduate student workers scanned a total of 3596 m of older cores that were lacking in basic data (primarily images and loop magnetic susceptibility). We organized and shipped materials for core curation for six cruises and lent out scanning equipment to collect data for three research cruises.

Our digitization, database and App capabilities increased with a switch to a new cloud server, making searches significantly faster with our database holdings now linked directly to our website. Users can now query the collections based on cruise, core or ship names, PI name, location, institution, etc. and see related datasets and basic metadata profiles on landing pages. In house, we aim to finalize the process for printing labels directly from the App, for core sections, rocks, and sample requests. For the website, we establish a data processing step that allows us to better serve CT scans (over 700 core sections will be available on our website), add features for downloading batches of data, and improve our methods for sharing related publications.

The OSU-MGR supports education by hosting workshops, early career national and international  schools, university classes, and tours and educational experiences to K-12 learners as well as intensive research programs through NSF REU program. We continue our outreach efforts in a variety of ways from hosting an NSF virtual townhall, developing twice-yearly newsletters to 240 repository and potential repository users, updating the OSU-MGR website with new additions to the collections, providing tours to CEOAS Geology alumni, working locally with the OSU Alumni Association developing a ?Knowledge Break? webinar and hosting the OSU Board of Trustees (who govern the University) for dinner and tours.

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2023
Modified by: Joseph S Stoner
